Research Support

Current Funding






KL2TR001854 (PIs: Siegel SJ, Burner ERE) NIH NCATS via SC CTSI Role: KL2 Mentored Career Development Scholar Period: July 2024 - Present Effort: 75%
Institutional Career Development Core providing training to become a clinical translational investigator.





Completed Funding






T32DK007740-24S1 (PI: Lewis JD) NIH NIDDK Role: T32 Trainee Period: July 2020 - June 2023
Clinical Epidemiology Training in Gastroenterology - Supplemental training slot on post-doctoral training program for clinical investigators in gastrointestinal clinical research.









3P42ES023720-01S1 (PI: Blair IK) NIH NIEHS Role: Co-Investigator Period: 2015 - 2016
Minority supplement grant to facilitate training in social epidemiology; primary research objective was to conduct a historical cohort study investigating mechanisms of non-occupational exposure to asbestos and subsequent risk of mesothelioma.

title: Projects
text:
Status: Active | Funding: To be added
Families caring for children with intestinal failure face unique challenges including complex medical regimens, frequent hospitalizations, and significant lifestyle modifications. This project aims to:

Develop and validate instruments to measure caregiver burden specific to pediatric intestinal failure
Identify modifiable factors associated with caregiver strain
Design interventions to support families

Key Methods: Survey development, psychometric validation, mixed methods






Status: Active | Funding: To be added
Leveraging multi-center registry data to understand long-term outcomes in children with short bowel syndrome. Research questions include:

Predictors of intestinal adaptation and enteral autonomy
Risk factors for complications including catheter-related bloodstream infections
Health-related quality of life outcomes

Key Methods: Cohort studies, survival analysis, machine learning






Status: Active | Funding: To be added
Examining disparities in access to specialized care and outcomes for children with complex gastrointestinal conditions:

Geographic variation in access to intestinal rehabilitation programs
Socioeconomic and racial/ethnic disparities in outcomes
Policy implications for improving equity

Key Methods: Administrative data analysis, geospatial analysis, mixed methods

title: Projects
text:
Collaborations
We welcome collaborations with researchers, clinicians, and patient advocates interested in improving outcomes for children with intestinal failure and their families.
Interested in collaborating? Contact us.

title: Agawu Lab
text:
We are a research group at Children’s Hospital Los Angeles and USC Keck School of Medicine focused on improving clinical outcomes for children with complex gastrointestinal conditions.
Our work combines clinical epidemiology, caregiver-centered outcomes research, and data science to understand and address the challenges facing pediatric patients with intestinal failure and their families.
Learn More About Our Research View Publications

title: Agawu Lab
text:
Research Focus


Clinical Epidemiology
Understanding disease patterns, outcomes, and risk factors in pediatric intestinal failure and related conditions using large-scale data analysis.


Caregiver Strain
Measuring and addressing the burden experienced by families caring for children with chronic complex conditions, with a focus on developing interventions to support caregivers.


Data Science
Leveraging modern analytical approaches including machine learning and advanced statistical methods to extract insights from clinical data.

title: Agawu Lab
text:
Current Projects






NoteCaregiver Burden in Pediatric Intestinal Failure



Investigating the multidimensional impact of caring for children with intestinal failure on families, including financial, emotional, and social domains.








NoteOutcomes in Pediatric Short Bowel Syndrome



Analyzing long-term outcomes and predictors of intestinal adaptation in children with short bowel syndrome using multi-center registry data.








NoteHealth Equity in Pediatric GI Care



Examining disparities in access to specialized care and outcomes for children with complex gastrointestinal conditions.

title: Agawu Lab
text:
Principal Investigator





Dr. Atu Agawu




Atu Agawu, MD, MPH, MSCE
Assistant Professor of Clinical Pediatrics Children’s Hospital Los Angeles USC Keck School of Medicine
Dr. Agawu is a pediatric gastroenterologist and clinical epidemiologist whose research focuses on improving outcomes for children with intestinal failure and understanding the experiences of their caregivers.
Read Full Bio

title: About
text:
Dr. Atu Agawu





Assistant Professor of Clinical Pediatrics Division of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition Children’s Hospital Los Angeles USC Keck School of Medicine
Dr. Agawu is a pediatric gastroenterologist and clinical epidemiologist specializing in the care of children with intestinal failure. He completed his undergraduate studies in Biomedical Engineering at Yale University, followed by his MD, MPH, and MSCE at the Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania.
He completed his pediatric residency and fellowship in pediatric gastroenterology at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, including T32 training in clinical epidemiology. He subsequently completed an Advanced Pediatric Nutrition Fellowship at Children’s Hospital Los Angeles and is currently a KL2 Mentored Career Development Scholar through the Southern California Clinical Translational Science Institute (SC CTSI).
His research focuses on understanding and improving clinical outcomes for children with intestinal failure, with particular emphasis on measuring and addressing the burden experienced by caregivers. He employs epidemiological methods and data science approaches to analyze large-scale clinical data and develop evidence-based interventions.

title: About
text:
Dr. Atu Agawu





Assistant Professor of Clinical Pediatrics Division of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition Children’s Hospital Los Angeles USC Keck School of Medicine
Dr. Agawu is a pediatric gastroenterologist and clinical epidemiologist specializing in the care of children with intestinal failure. He completed his undergraduate studies in Biomedical Engineering at Yale University, followed by his MD, MPH, and MSCE at the Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania.
He completed his pediatric residency and fellowship in pediatric gastroenterology at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, including T32 training in clinical epidemiology. He subsequently completed an Advanced Pediatric Nutrition Fellowship at Children’s Hospital Los Angeles and is currently a KL2 Mentored Career Development Scholar through the Southern California Clinical Translational Science Institute (SC CTSI).
His research focuses on understanding and improving clinical outcomes for children with intestinal failure, with particular emphasis on measuring and addressing the burden experienced by caregivers. He employs epidemiological methods and data science approaches to analyze large-scale clinical data and develop evidence-based interventions.

title: About
text:
Research Interests

Pediatric intestinal failure - Outcomes research, quality improvement, and clinical epidemiology
Caregiver burden - Measurement, predictors, and interventions to support families
Health equity - Disparities in access to specialized pediatric GI care
Data science - Application of machine learning and advanced analytics to clinical questions

title: About
text:
For Prospective Trainees
We welcome inquiries from medical students, residents, and fellows interested in research opportunities in pediatric GI epidemiology and outcomes research.
If you are interested in joining the lab, please send an email with:

Your CV
A brief statement of research interests
Your timeline and availability

Contact Dr. Agawu
